body: @melix "If one Groovy sees, say, a partial file (written by the other Groovy) then you're in trouble." -- If one Groovy sees a partial file, it will fail to read the object successfully, the cache will fail to init either, the default resolving behavior will be chosen. However it's better to avoid the potential trouble you mentioned.

@melix "I would also avoid adding another third party dependency just for this: this is core groovy." -- Yep, I agree with you. so the feature is **NOT** enabled by default and the third party dependency is **optional**, as you can see, the dependency is `compileOnly` and it will not be included in groovy distributions.
```groovy
compileOnly "io.github.classgraph:classgraph:$classgraphVersion" // for compilation only
testRuntime "io.github.classgraph:classgraph:$classgraphVersion" // for running tests
```
LGTM

Also, I wonder whether folks would like the checkbox and filename saved under the OS preferences. Might be worth an email to the mailing list to see if folks have a strong preference. At the moment you need to set them each time you start the console.

If someone has an existing class that extends `ASTNode` and provides custom visitation, it will be extending `visit`, not `accept`.  Your changes have `accept` being called throughout the codebase.  So for backwards compatibility, the default `accept` needs to call to the potentially overloaded `visit` until such time as `visit` is removed.

Another problem this change will introduce: Any class that extends one of the `ASTNode` subclasses and intends to override the behavior of a parent's `visit` or even call to the parent's `visit` could be getting something unexpected.  Would a call `super.visit(visitor)` reliably map to the parent's `accept` method?

And if any class already has a method `accept(GroovyCodeVisitor)`, it will suddenly be an override.  (Probably less likely, but a consideration to make.)

Eric makes some good points. Maybe making this change is more trouble than it is worth. The visit/accept names are after all just a convention. Some languages use dispatch instead of visit by convention for instance. I agree that using visit/visit as our convention is probably unique if not a little strange but most of us have become familiar with it. An alternative might be to just rename the parameter from visitor -> acceptedVisitor. And perhaps add some Groovydoc: "... accepts a visitor .." or similar.

Since we can not keep backawards compatiblity via adding an alias `visit` method, I will close the PR and the related JIRA ticket.

P.S.  right/meaningful names can help us think well

All of them seem to be failing with an NPE at `org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.asm.sc.StaticTypesMethodReferenceExpressionWriter.createParametersWithExactType(StaticTypesMethodReferenceExpressionWriter.java:207)`, e.g. : https://travis-ci.org/apache/groovy/jobs/517407421#L2283 just searched for 'caused by' in the travis log and it's almost all the same source. But, according to github, that line is a comment: https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/d744dfbbdc0741750e3af0b233c46af298a1e724/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/sc/StaticTypesMethodReferenceExpressionWriter.java#L204-L212

If it's an infrastructure problem you could try closing and re-opening the PR, which should trigger travis to run again.
Well, I should change groovyc Ant stuff anyway, and that will make it re-kick.

+1 with the following comments:
* I haven't done a performance check yet but will try to do that soon
* I think some of the functionality in ReflectionUtils might be better in VMPlugin? Since we already have some similar functionality there?
* If we do need to backport to 2_5_X, some of the lambda code will need to be back-ported

> I think some of the functionality in ReflectionUtils might be better in VMPlugin? Since we already have some similar functionality there?

`ReflectionUtils` provides some facade API for `VMPlugin` , which will make our life easy IMO ;-)

> > I think some of the functionality in ReflectionUtils might be better in VMPlugin? Since we already have some similar functionality there?
> 
> `ReflectionUtils` provides some facade API for `VMPlugin` , which will make our life easy IMO ;-)

For me there are two code smells but I don't think either would be hard to fix:
* Given that VMPlugin is designed to run the correct method for the version of the JVM we are using, we shouldn't need to also check the version
* We have some functionality in ReflectionUtils and some similar functionality in VMPlugin and it's not clear to me that they aren't all at the same level - if that is the case we'd need to document it that way but I suspect we can consolidate into one level

Hi, I merged this but tweaked it to use Hsqldb not Oracle. Our build assumes Hsqldb for the tests unless driver details are overridden with properties. We don't have Oracle available in our current CI environments. Thanks for the suggestion.

> Given that VMPlugin is designed to run the correct method for the version of the JVM we are using, we shouldn't need to also check the version

Agreed.

> We have some functionality in ReflectionUtils and some similar functionality in VMPlugin and it's not clear to me that they aren't all at the same level - if that is the case we'd need to document it that way but I suspect we can consolidate into one level

What I know about vm plugins is just to provide the plug-in functions for different JVMs. But vm plugins have little abstraction, just some concrete implementations. It's better to rely on abstraction if we want some stable API. (My 2 cents)
How about moving the implementation of the following method to VMPlugin(e.g. Java5-Java9 plugins), then add a method in `ReflectionUtils` with same signatures delegating to the method in VMPlugin.
https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/2a8effa0880d245f1a01417974c812aac9410bd4/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/reflection/ReflectionUtils.java#L143
Something like that might be close to what I had in mind! ;-)
I'll change the code tonight.

I merged in the test case additions commit from this PR. The other commits have been superseded. Thanks!
The build failure is highlighting the case where the config of the existing groovyclassloader is different to the supplied config.
Oops, thanks @paulk-asert. I didn't notice the fail.

That certainly fixed the breaking test. CompilerConfiguration is in general mutable - so being able to get the config allows mutation more readily which isn't ideal. I'll have a ponder whether there might be a better alternative. We have made the default configuration immutable recently, so maybe not as bad an issue as previously. If you passed in a config and retained a reference to it, you could change the config in any case.
As you are trying to modify the old parser, the test code is parsed by the new Parrot parser by default, so I think the test code can not cover the code changes of the old parser.
Merged, thanks.
Merged with a few tweaks
JVM option `groovy.allow.illegal.access.properties` is added to enable illegal access properties for backward compatibility(Note: `false` is default value)
Merged. Thanks!
